It instructs AI agents to read/write code files and execute standard Gradle commands for Java development. All capabilities are necessary and appropriate for backend development tasks. No suspicious patterns, obfuscation, or malicious code detected.

low_findings.title: Gradle command execution for build and testing
low_findings.description: The skill instructs AI to execute `./gradlew check` (lines 224-226) and `./gradlew bootRun` (lines 244-246) for linting, testing, and server startup verification. These are legitimate Gradle commands for Java/Spring Boot development. Risk is low because: commands run in project context only, standard Java build tool, required for quality verification.

content.user_title: Build Spring Boot backends with tests and quality checks
content.value_statement: Creating backend APIs with Spring Boot requires following proper patterns, database migrations, and passing quality gates. This skill provides a complete development workflow with test coverage requirements and lint validation.
actual_capabilities: Design and implement RESTful APIs with Spring Boot
Implement Controller, Service, and Mapper layers
Write JUnit 5 unit tests with Mockito
Run `./gradlew check` for lint and coverage validation
Verify server startup and API functionality
limitations: Focuses on Spring Boot/MyBatis stack only
Requires existing project structure with Gradle
Does not generate frontend code or deployment configurations

use_cases.title: Implement new REST endpoints
use_cases.description: Add new API endpoints following project conventions with proper layer separation and tests

use_cases.title: Create database schemas
use_cases.description: Design database tables with Flyway migrations and update related entity/DTO classes

use_cases.title: Verify code quality
use_cases.description: Run lint checks and ensure test coverage meets 80% threshold before merge

prompt_templates.title: Create simple CRUD API
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a new REST API endpoint for [resource-name] with standard CRUD operations following the project patterns. Include Flyway migration, entity, DTO, mapper, service, and controller. Ensure 80% test coverage.

prompt_templates.title: Add validation rules
prompt_templates.prompt: Add input validation to the [existing-endpoint] API. Use Bean Validation annotations and return proper error responses. Update unit tests to cover validation scenarios.

prompt_templates.title: Write integration tests
prompt_templates.prompt: Create integration tests for the [api-name] endpoint. Test success cases, validation errors, and edge cases. Verify coverage meets the 80% threshold.

prompt_templates.title: Optimize database queries
prompt_templates.prompt: Review the [mapper-name] mapper for N+1 query issues or missing indexes. Optimize the SQL queries and add appropriate result maps. Verify changes with `./gradlew check`.

output_examples.input: Create a user profile API with CRUD operations
output: Created UserProfile entity with required columns
Added 12 unit tests covering all CRUD operations

best_practices: Follow existing patterns from similar implementations in the codebase
Use product.util package utilities instead of creating duplicates
Run `./gradlew check` and fix all issues before committing
anti_patterns: Skipping test coverage validation before merge
Writing try-catch blocks instead of using ExceptionHandler
Manually logging when AOP handles logging automatically

faq.question: Which Java frameworks does this skill support?
faq.answer: This skill is optimized for Spring Boot with MyBatis. Other frameworks require manual adaptation of patterns.

faq.question: What test coverage threshold is enforced?
faq.answer: Minimum 80% line coverage is required. Business logic should achieve 90% coverage.

faq.question: Can this skill work with Maven instead of Gradle?
faq.answer: The skill references Gradle commands. Maven users need to translate `./gradlew check` and bootRun to equivalent Maven goals.

faq.question: Is my code safe when using this skill?
faq.answer: Yes. This skill only reads and writes within your project directory. No data is sent to external services.

faq.question: Why does the skill reference specific utility classes?
faq.answer: The skill references project-specific utilities like SecurityUtils and JwtUtil to encourage reuse and avoid duplicating existing functionality.

faq.question: How does this differ from generic code generation?
faq.answer: This skill follows your project's specific conventions, coding rules, and existing utilities. It enforces quality gates and documentation updates.
